ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FACTORIES SET UP UNDER
INDUSTRIALISATION POLICY
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Finance (a) how many factories have been set up under the Industrialisation Policy up to the latest convenient date; (b) how much foreign capital is invested; (c) how much local capital is invested; (d) how many workers are employed in those factories; (e) how many of those factories are operating satisfactorily; and (f) how many of those factories have closed down or ceased operation and how many workers became unemployed as a consequence.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the annual

Column: 236

Census of Industrial Production which covers establishments employing ten or more workers, there were 1,555 manufacturing establishments at the end of 1968, employing 72,200 workers. In 1959, there were 531 establishments employing 25,600 workers. In other words, factories and industrial workers nearly trebled since 1959. This covers the Member's queries (a) and (d) as appeared in the Order Paper.

    As at June 1969, foreign paid-up capital amounted to $637 million. Of this, $264 million or 42 per cent came, from local sources, while $373 million or, 58 per cent came from abroad.

    The actual capital investment in fixed assets exceeds the above and is estimated, at some $780 million. This is much higher than the paid-up capital, but is made possible because most of the companies are able to get credit facilities

Column: 237

from various sources, and, besides, in most cases, land in industrial estates is leased from the Government, while buildings are either leased or mortgaged. Such credit availability has enabled sound enterprises to commence with lower capital requirements.

    The above statistics on capital investments are based on a quarterly survey conducted by the Economic Development Board. The survey covers all pioneer firms in Jurong and non-pioneer firms in the nine major industrial estates and is not comparable with the Census of Industrial Production. The above covers the Member's queries (b) and (c).

    With a few exceptions, Singapore factories are active and operating satisfactorily. Of the pioneer firms, nine have ceased operation. Their closure affected roughly 300 workers. These workers were mostly absorbed by other establishments. This last bit covers the Member's queries (e) and (f) as appeared in the Order Paper.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that some factories in Jurong have a shortage of workers, especially technicians and artisans? If such a situation exists, can the Parliamentary Secretary inform the House what measures the Government intends to take to deal with it?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, while this question should properly be directed to the Minister for Labour, I suppose I can just say a few words. There is evidence recently that there is some shortage of skilled labour. The Government is taking all necessary steps to remedy this situation.

UNIFORMED CIVIL SERVANTS
(Change of uniforms)


    2. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Finance whether it is intended to change the uniforms of the other uniformed civil servants besides Police and Customs officers.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, uniforms

Column: 238

are issued to civil servants who are required to wear uniforms for easy recognition or identification by the public to prevent undue wear and tear to their own personal clothing, or for reasons of prestige and ceremony.

    In the case of the Police and Customs, uniforms are provided mainly for purposes of easy recognition and identification. As they belong to law-enforcing forces, their uniforms should have the appearance of smartness and dignity to command better respect, it is with this object in mind that their uniforms were changed.

    Where a similar need exists, the uniforms of a particular group of officers will be changed, but uniforms will not be changed just for the sake of a change.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I know which particular group of officers' uniforms will be changed?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, as far as I know, no other group exists which needs a change of uniforms. But if the Member can make out a case for a change, his suggestion will be considered and, if found necessary, the uniform will be changed. But as I said, the uniform will not be changed just for the sake of a change.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Now that a change of uniform for the police has been enforced, will the Minister also change the uniforms of police cadets in schools who are still using the same old uniforms?

    Mr Tang See Chim: There is no plan just now to change the uniforms of school police cadets.

TAX RELIEFS ON PREMIUMS FOR GROUP MEDICAL
INSURANCE SCHEMES


    3. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Finance if he will consider granting tax reliefs on premiums for group medical insurance schemes which have been introduced by collective

Column: 239

agreements, in the same manner as reliefs are allowed on premiums for life insurance policies and contributions to provident funds.

    Mr Tang See Chim (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, premiums for group medical insurance under most collective agreements are payable by employers. As such, they are trade or business expenses and have always been deductible from income for tax purposes.

    There are a few schemes under collective agreements in which employees may voluntarily participate and make small payments to cover themselves and their families for hospitalisation and surgical benefits. Under the law, medical expenses of the community at large are not deductible for income tax purposes and there is no valid reason to give special relief for contributions by employees to group medical insurance schemes.

    Such contributions are similar to payments for personal accident policies, for which no income tax relief is given, and are not in the same category as provident funds or life insurance policies which are, in fact, savings schemes, although the latter provide for capital sums being payable on death.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Does the Parliamentary Secretary not recognise the fact that if group medical insurance schemes become popular, it will be a great boon to the Government in the sense that members of medical insurance schemes who become hospitalised will generally get themselves warded in Class I and Class II wards instead of the virtually free Class III wards?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Medical insurance schemes are for the benefit of the persons taking out these schemes. As a general rule, there is no income tax relief for accident schemes and, as I have just said, they are not in the same category as life insurance schemes which are, in fact, savings schemes.

Column: 240



    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Will the Parliamentary Secretary consider changing the Income Tax Ordinance so that tax relief can be granted on premiums paid for medical insurance schemes?

    Mr Tang See Chim: My Ministry has found no valid reason for making any change to the existing Income Tax Ordinance so as to give relief to such contributions.

FACTORIES ORDINANCE
(Inclusion of I.L.O, safety regulations)


    4. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour if he will consider widening the scope of the provisions in the Factories Ordinance by including the safety regulations recommended by the International Labour Organisation.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the scope of the existing Factories Ordinance is sufficiently comprehensive for safeguarding the health and safety of persons employed in factories. Relevant International Labour Organisation safety regulations have already been used by the Factory Inspectorate to guide the factory occupiers in safety and health practices in such industries as the iron and steel industry, the chemical industry, textile mills and industrial gases manufacturing plants. Further, there is provision in the Ordinance for the Minister to make special regulations to uphold higher standards of safety and health of workers in industry where the risk of bodily injury is abnormal.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): It appears to me that there are no adequate safety regulations in respect of building sites. With the tendency now for buildings to go higher up, I think it is high time to look into this particular aspect of safety regulations. Will the Parliamentary Secretary please tell the House whether he will look into this matter?

Column: 241



    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the construction of factories, all aspects of safety are being looked into by the various Ministries concerned.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary not recognise that rapid industrialisation has given rise to a lot of harm and safety problems, making it imperative to strengthen the provisions of the Factories Ordinance?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, as I have indicated just now, the present Ordinance is adequate to meet the present requirements. I think the House was told yesterday by the Minister for Health that the Industrial Health Unit was going to play a major part on the whole question of industrial safety.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that the appropriate authorities in his Ministry - the Factory Inspectorate - refer to the I.L.O. recommendations for guidance?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: It is difficult to hear the Member.

    Mr Speaker: The Member's question was whether the Parliamentary Secretary appreciated that the factory inspectors, in fact, refer to the I.L.O. recommendations for guidance.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: The I.L.O. recommendations are being implemented.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: If the I.L.O. recommendations are referred to for guidance, does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that suitable I.L.O. recommendations be made part of the Factories Ordinance?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: It is not just a simple matter of putting the recommendations into our present legislation. This sort of thing will take time. As far as the present Ordinance is concerned, we feel that it is quite adequate to meet our present needs. However, I am sure that when the time comes, steps will be taken to deal with such matters. I think the next question of the Member on the Order Paper will deal with that.

Column: 242



    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, arising out of this question, may we know how old is the Factories Ordinance?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I am afraid I have no idea of how old it is,

    Mr Ho See Beng: If that is the case, the word "adequate" is not very appropriate.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that the Factory Inspectorate believe that the Factories Ordinance is inadequate?. He can refer to the 1968 Annual Report of the Ministry of Labour under the appropriate section.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir,I think the Member is anticipating the answers to his next question, because he is now dealing with the next question.

FACTORY INSPECTORATE
(Increase and upgrading of staff)


    5. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour if he will consider (i) strengthening the Factory inspectorate by increasing the numbers of Senior Inspectors and Inspectors of Factories; (ii) upgrading the posts of Chief Inspector, Senior Inspector and Inspector of Factories and (iii) re-organising the Factory Inspectorate to increase its enforcement capability.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Factory Inspectorate has already been strengthened by the creation of two posts of Inspector of Factories, one in 1968 and another in 1969. In 1967, the Factory Inspectorate had only four posts of Inspector of Factories in addition to the Chief Inspector of Factories and the Senior Inspector of Factories. The established posts of Inspector of Factories have now been increased to six in the I 969-70 Estimates. Although all the posts of Inspector of Factories have been filled, two of the officers have been taken into national service. To make up

Column: 243

for the loss of service of these two Inspectors of Factories, provision has been made in the 1969-70 Estimates for a supernumerary Inspector of Factories to be recruited. Attempts are now being made to fill this post on a temporary basis until the return of the two Inspectors of Factories from national service, one in April and the other in September 1970.

    The salary scale of Factory Inspectors, including the Chief Inspector of Factories and Senior Inspector of Factories who are all qualified engineers, was revised in July this year to bring it into line with that of engineers employed in other departments of Government, such as the Public Works Department. Since the staff in the department is limited in number, consisting in all of 18 persons, Government has not seen fit to upgrade the post of Chief Inspector of Factories and Senior Inspector of Factories. If, however, the department is reorganised, consideration will be given to upgrade these two posts.

    Recognising the importance of industrial safety in the context of rapid industrialisation, Government has obtained the services of two International Executive Service Corps experts to make a study of industrial safety and health in industrial establishments. They have completed their reports and their recommendations are being studied by the Government with a view to their implementation.

    The reorganisation of the Factory Inspectorate to increase its effectiveness is one of the recommendations made by the experts. However, industrial safety and health is not just a problem of enforcement. Both management and workers at factory level must themselves ensure that the laws enacted for the health and safety of workers are strictly observed.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that a staff complement of one Chief Inspector of Factories, one Senior Inspector of Factories and five Inspectors of Factories

Column: 244

is far from adequate to ensure that the minimum standards of safety, health and welfare of persons engaged in factories are observed? When the position in 1968 is compared to that in 1959 when industrialisation was first mooted, there was one Chief Inspector of Factories, an Industrial Training Officer --

    Mr Speaker: Order. Inche Abdul Aziz, what you are saying sounds more like a speech than a supplementary question. What is the question?

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that the position in 1968 is far from favourable or satisfactory as compared to the position in 1959?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think every department would like to increase its staff, but there is always a limit. I am sure as time goes on and when the need is such as to enable us to convince the Minister for Finance, I am sure more posts could be created.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Does the Parliamentary Secretary not agree that with rapid industrialisation and increase in the number of factories and diversity of the kinds of factories, a total of seven Inspectors of Factories is far from adequate and satisfactory to cope with the cases in hand?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already indicated that we have increased the number of posts in the Factory Inspectorate and that is as far as we can go just now.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the present number of Inspectors of Factories deal efficiently and expeditiously with all the cases in hand?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I do not know whether the Member can indicate an instance where the Inspectors of Factories were not available to deal with any case in hand. As far as I know, there has been no complaint of any negligence or unsatisfactory performance of their duties. But, as I said, if we can make

Column: 245

out a strong case that there is really a need for an increase in the number of Inspectors of Factories, I am sure the Minister for Finance will give it sympathetic consideration.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary say whether he agrees that this is a question of priority? If there are frequent occurrences of accidents in factories, I think we should consider it as a priority question.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, I fully agree with what the Member for Sembawang has said.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour has said that he will prepare a strong case to the Minister for Finance if there is such a need. I want to know whether his Ministry at this juncture think that there is such a need and whether, in fact, his Ministry is taking steps to prepare such a case for the consideration of the Minister for Finance for the provision of extra personnel for this particular department.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, I have already indicated in my answer that the number of posts has already been increased in the 1969-70 Estimates. I think that is as far as we can go at this stage.

    An hon. Member: Is there a need?

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, what assurance can the Parliamentary Secretary give to the House that persons of the highest calibre arid qualifications are engaged as Inspectors of Factories?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Sir, that is the common practice when recruiting Government officers.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Sir, what are the qualifications of Inspectors of Factories?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not think that is a supplementary question that properly arises out of the original question. In any event, the information

Column: 246

asked is easily available in publications of the Public Service Commission.

    6. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Defence whether and what additional expenditure has been incurred by the issue of the new uniform to Police personnel.

ROAD LINKING PUNGGOL ROAD
WITH TAMPINES ROAD
(Construction)


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether there are any plans to, construct a road linking Punggol Road with Tampines Road; and where the link road will be constructed.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Works Department has looked into several possibilities of constructing a link road to join Punggol Road with Tampines Road. Any link road to be constructed would run through swampy land. Further, a bridge must be built across Sungei Serangoon. In view of the high cost involved, there is no immediate economic justification for such a project.

ELECTRIFICATION OF BUKIT
PANJANG CONSTITUENCY


    8. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Public Utilities Board how long it will be before the Board completes the electrification of the Bukit Panjang Constituency.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Utilities Board expects to complete the electrification scheme of Bukit Panjang Constituency by the end of 1972.

    Mr P. Selvadurai (Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister give the House some particulars of the schemes that have been implemented and also the schemes that are under planning at the moment?

    Mr Barker: Since 1963 up to date, about 24 schemes to provide electricity supplies to about 674 authorised houses have been completed at a cost of about $457,000. There are, at present, 11 schemes which have been approved for implementation to cater for another 427 authorised houses. These will be carried out in stages and are expected to be completed before mid-1971 at a cost of about $317,000. Survey and planning of the schemes to provide electricity supplies for the resettlement of 86 shop-houses at the l4½ milestone Woodlands Road are under consideration by the Board. In addition, seven other schemes are now under active survey and planning in Bukit Panjang.

MOSQUITO MENACE
(Setting up of inter-departmental Committee)


    9. Mr P. Selvadurai asked the Minister for Health if he will take steps to constitute an inter-departmental committee that will receive from the public complaints relating to the mosquito menace and take effective action thereon without the need to pass the responsibility from one Ministry to another.

Column: 248



    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, an Operations Room was set up in the Ministry of Health on 1st October, 1968, for the purpose of receiving all complaints relating to public health, including those on the mosquito menace, and dealing with them expeditiously. Every complaint received is investigated, if substantiated, remedial measures are promptly taken. Where the matter complained of is the responsibility of another Ministry, Government department or statutory board, or where the problem can only be solved by such other Ministry, Government department or statutory board, the complaint is immediately referred to them for necessary action to be taken. Quite often joint action is taken to deal satisfactorily with the complaint.

    Since the existing arrangement I have described has worked satisfactorily, I do not think it is necessary to constitute a special inter-departmental committee just to deal with mosquito complaints.

INCREASE OF WATER CHARGES
(Statement by the Minister for Finance)


3.00 p.m.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, complementary with the construction of low-cost houses by the Housing and Development Board has been the expansion of modern sanitation facilities throughout the Republic. In 1960, 36 per cent of the population was served by modern sanitation. The percentage now is 55 per cent. Some $69 million have been spent over the last nine years in extending sewerage facilities not only to new industrial and housing estates but also to outlying areas which hitherto had not been provided with such facilities.

    It is the Government's intention to make modern sanitation available to every home within economic reach. We will spend approximately $60 million for the period 1968-73. To help finance the scheme, the World Bank has agreed to a loan of $18 million to meet the foreign exchange component of the sewerage projects, the first time the World Bank

Column: 249

has given a loan for sewerage development anywhere in the world.

    Up to now, the capital and operational costs of the Sewerage Department have not been covered by the revenue collected. To be quite candid, no one knew what returns we got on expenditure as the sums had never been worked out. In the course of negotiations with the World Bank for the loan, the Bank made it clear that approval of the loan was conditional on the sewage fees being revised. Further, fees were to be linked to the volume of water consumed and the revenue by 1972 was to be adequate to cover operating expenses plus interest on capital amortisation. It is a cardinal principle with the World Bank that investments must pay their way.

    In compliance with the conditions set out by the World Bank, it is necessary to raise the charges for water. The increases will be as follows:

    (i) Domestic users of water will pay an additional 20 cents per thousand gallons of metered water in addition to a fee of $2 per fitting per month;

    (ii) In the case of non-domestic premises, the charge will be 50 cents per thousand gallons of metered water;

    (iii) In the case of industries utilising water in their end-products, meters will be fixed to assess the amount of water used for industrial purposes and not discharged into sewers.

    These fees will be collected by the Public Utilities Board on behalf of the Government. The additional payments from domestic premises will vary between 20 cents and $1 per month for more than 55 per cent of the population, while another 30 per cent will pay between $1 and $2 per month. Commercial and industrial premises will also bear a share of the costs, varying from $2.50 to $15 per month in the case of coffee-shops, and $15 to $75 per month for the smaller industrial premises.

    In order that the increases in utility charges will not be reflected in poorer households, the current exemption from the P.U.B. sales tax on consumers whose bills are below $10 a month will be extended to those whose bills are below

Column: 250

$12 a month. The five per cent tax payable on bills between $11 and $20 will now be applicable to bills between $12 and $25 a month and the ten per cent rate of tax will in future apply only to bills over $25. In spite of the increases, the return of investments in sewerage is expected to be no more than two per cent on capital invested.

    Legislation to give effect to these increased charges will be introduced at this sitting of Parliament, and when the Bill is passed early next year the increases will take effect.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think this is a Christmas present for the thousands of consumers. I have two questions, Sir. First, what is the number of consumers who are making use of the sewage schemes? Secondly, the Minister for Finance mentioned that the revenue returns would be only two per cent. In other words, it is only $1.2 million. Will there be further increases later on when the Minister will probably come here with another Ministerial statement?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, the Member has not been listening with the attention that the statement deserves. As I said in my closing remarks, these increases will take effect next year and therefore he and his friends can spend their Christmas without undue concern that the water bills are going up.

    As regards the two per cent return, I do not know how the Member arrived at the figure of a yield of $1.2 million. When I said a two per cent return on capital, I meant a two per cent return on the capital that had been spent in all sewerage works in the past. The Member will agree that this is a very low return on capital investment. For instance, if you were to invest money in business, you would expect a return of at least 20 per cent; but this being a public utility, Government had to settle for a very low rate of return indeed. Of course, I agree with the Member that this is most unfortunate, but let us reflect on the good fortune in the past when these people were getting subsidised services. In the past, as I have said, there was no

Column: 251

accounting on this score, and what happened was that the general tax revenue had gone into meeting the losses sustained by running the sewerage system. With these new charges, the Sewerage Department should at least no longer be in the red.

    Whether there would be further increases or not, no one can say. It all depends on a number of things which it is not possible to predict now. For instance, if wages and costs go up, then naturally the charges will also have to go up.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, the figure of $1.2 million was arrived at as a result of the $60 million loan, apart from the other capital investment involved. Just now the Finance Minister mentioned that the Sewerage Department had been running at a loss. I would be grateful if he could inform the House of the amount of losses up to date.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I said in my statement, no one knew what the losses were because no one did the sums. But the Member for Punggol will recollect that the Sewerage Department was at one time a department of the former City Council. When the City Council hived off into different departments with the main utilities department forming the Public Utilities Board, the treasurer then knew what the position was and passed on the Sewerage Department to the Government. He was under no illusion that this was a losing proposition. So Government had to carry this baby, and this was carried, as I said, out of the general tax revenue until we applied for the World Bank loan. The World Bank did the calculations and said that this loss has now got to be made good.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, is it correct to say that it is a loss because it is a service to the public and not a trade?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes, it is a loss in the sense that those receiving the services did not pay for the cost. It is like people riding on the Singapore

Column: 252

Traction Company's buses and the company is losing money - in the same way that the Sewerage Department is losing money.
